title: Creating an Inequality
text: First, we must transfer the word problem into an inequality that represents Mona's budget.
speech: First, we must transfer the word problem into an inequality that represents Mona's budget.
pacedSpeech: First, we must transfer the word problem into an inequality that represents Mona's budget.

title: Creating an Inequality
text: We know that Mona has a budget of $285 and the Fun Zone charges $19 per child. Let's call the number of child $$x$$, so we have the inequality $$19x \leq 285$$.
speech: We know that Mona has a budget of $285 and the Fun Zone charges $19 per child. Let's call the number of child  x , so we have the inequality  19 x is less than or equal to, 285 .
pacedSpeech: We know that Mona has a budget of $285 and the Fun Zone charges $19 per child. Let's call the number of child   x
, so we have the inequality   19 x is less than or equal to, 285

title: Solving the Inequality
text: Now, we must solve the inequality for $$x$$ by algebrically manipulating it.
speech: Now, we must solve the inequality for  x  by algebrically manipulating it.
pacedSpeech: Now, we must solve the inequality for   x

title: Solving the Inequality
text: To do this, we can divide both sides by $$19$$ to isolate $$x$$. We now have $$x \leq 15$$ as our inequality.
speech: To do this, we can divide both sides by  19  to isolate  x . We now have  x is less than or equal to 15  as our inequality.
pacedSpeech: To do this, we can divide both sides by   19
. We now have   x is less than or equal to 15

title: Creating a Sentence-Answer
text: Since $$x$$ must be less than or equal to $$15$$, what is the maximum number of children Mona can have at the party?
speech: Since  x  must be less than or equal to  15 , what is the maximum number of children Mona can have at the party?

, what is the maximum number of children Mona can have at the party?
